answers.answer: You may be on too much medicine with your blood pressure being so low.  Generally the mitral regurgitation needs to be severe before repair is needed.  Sometimes a trans-esophogel echo can help decide how severe the regurgitation is  and   whether the valve can be repaired.  Bileaflet repairs are harder for the surgeon  and the success is less.

question: I am a 46 yo female with bileaflet MVP with moderate regurg and three stents in LAD.  I am obviously on a multitude of medications now to try to manage the value issue and control any further buildup.  I have NEVER had high cholesterol (my ratio has always been excellent, triglycerides have never been out of range),  have never smoked, no high blood pressure, rarely drink (maybe 1 drink 2-3 times a year!), no diabetes but I am overweight (by about 50 lbs - 20 of that in the last year).  I have hypothyroid - not Hashimoto's.  Have paternal family history of CAD, bypasses, high blood pressure and strokes.  Grandmother died as a result of episode of high blood pressure which caused succession of strokes.  Two uncles (bypass w stroke, quad bypass), two aunts (bypass w stroke, medical mgmt of CAD and hbp)  and my dad (CAD diagnosed in his 50s - needs bypass but won't go).I now take Sythroid, Plavix, Aspirin, Lipitor, Coreg CR, Spironolactone (originally for a hormone imbalance but now also to keep fluid off) and my dr recently added lisinopril (after I was unable to take altace).  Between the Coreg CR and the lisinopril my bp is now averaging 85 over 55.  As you can imagine this leaves me wrung out.  My dr is pretty insistent on the lisinopril and has reduced coreg cr to accommodate the bp drop when lisinopril was added which was in the 71/48 range.Over the course of the last year the regurg has not progressed measurably but the size if the left atrium has.  At least one EKG recently has noted atrial flutter.I am concerned about other health problems due to the amount of medication I may be on for an undetermined amount of time.  I understand that I do not fit the criteria yet for a valve repair yet although I am clearly experiencingsymptoms.  Additionally, the times my cardiologist and I have discussed the valve he keeps saying replace instead of repair.  I understand that most can be repaired these days and don't want to miss my window of opportunity there.My questions are -Does the echo have to formally read "severe" before I become a candidate for repair?If it is clear the MVP is a problem and repairs are successful these days much of the time wouldn't it be more prudent to fix the valve while I am younger and in better health vs worse heart health and after years of the side effects of the medications?  I am not sure why if they know what the problem is, that it is degenerative and a repair is possible why the repair would be delayed.  Are bileaflet fixes less successful?
title: MVP - Timing of repair
